facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 205 of 1956 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 205 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated May 26, 1954 of Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 127 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated May 26, 1954, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 127 of 1950.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 25, 1961 by KAPUR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. January 25. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-This is an appeal against the judgment and decree of the High Court

facts.text: Appellant was the defendant in the original suit.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was the defendant in the suit out of which this appeal has arisen and respondent No. 1 was the plaintiff, and the second respondent was a proforma defendant.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 was the plaintiff in the original suit.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was the defendant in the suit out of which this appeal has arisen and respondent No. 1 was the plaintiff, and the second respondent was a proforma defendant.

facts.text: Second respondent was a proforma defendant in the original suit.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was the defendant in the suit out of which this appeal has arisen and respondent No. 1 was the plaintiff, and the second respondent was a proforma defendant.

facts.text: On February 4, 1941, respondent sold the property in dispute to the appellant for Rs. 10,000.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of this case are these On February 4, 1941, the respondent sold the property in dispute to the appellant for a sum of Rs. 10,000.

facts.text: On February 10, 1941, there was an agreement for reconveyance within a period up to February 10, 1943, for Rs. 10,001.

anchor.surface_text: On February 10, 1941, there was an agreement for reconveyance within a period up to February 10, 1943, for a sum of Rs. 10,001.

facts.text: Clause 3 of the agreement stated purchase to be completed by February 10, 1943, time being essence, on payment of Rs. 10,001 vendor to reconvey free from encumbrances.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant clause of this agreement was the third clause which was as follows - Clause 3.-The purchase shall be companypleted by the purchasers within two years, i.e., to say on or before the 10th day of February, 1943, time being the essence of the companytract. If the purchasers shall on or before the 10th day of February, 1943, pay to the vendor a sum of Rs. 10,001 the vendor shall at the companyt of the purchasers execute such companyveyance as may be necessary for companyveying and transferring its right, title and interest in the said property free from encumbrances, if any, created by it.

facts.text: On November 26, 1942, solicitor for respondent No. 1 wrote to appellant stating ready and willing to complete purchase on payment of Rs. 10,001, sent draft conveyance subject to search for encumbrances.

anchor.surface_text: On November 26, 1942, the solicitor for respondent No. 1 wrote a letter to the appellant stating that that respondent was ready and willing to have the purchase companypleted as early as possible on payment of Rs. 10,001. Along with that letter a draft companyveyance was sent for approval but all this was subject to the result of a search as to the encumbrances, if any, created by the appellant.

facts.text: On November 30, 1942, solicitors for appellant wrote back requesting inspection of the agreement of sale.

anchor.surface_text: On November 30, 1942, the solicitors for the appellant companypany wrote back saying that immediate arrangements should be made for giving inspection of the agreement of sale on which the respondents were relying as the appellant was unable to trace the companyy of the said agreement from its record.

facts.text: On December 11, 1942, respondent's solicitor sent letter stating client eager to complete purchase, consideration money ready, awaiting approved draft.

anchor.surface_text: Again on December 11, 1942, the respondents solicitor sent a letter stating My client is very eager to companyplete the purchase and the full companysideration money therefore is lying idle in his hands awaiting, the return of the relative draft companyveyance as approved by you on your clients behalf.

facts.text: On December 18, 1942, appellant's solicitors replied denying any concluded or valid agreement for sale.

anchor.surface_text: To this the reply of the appellants solicitors dated December 18, 1942, was- Our clients deny that there was any companycluded or valid agreement for sale with your client or with any other person in respect of the above premises.

facts.text: On June 10, 1943, respondent No. 1 filed suit for specific performance and alternatively for redemption treating transaction as mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: On June 10, 1943, respondent No. 1 filed a suit for specific performance and in the alternative for redemption on the footing that the transaction was in reality a mortgage.

facts.text: Trial court dismissed the suit on May 16, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt dismissed the suit oil May 16, 1950, holding that the transaction on the basis of which the suit was brought was number a mortgage but was out and out sale with an agreement for repurchase

facts.text: Trial court held transaction was out and out sale with agreement for repurchase, not mortgage, and right to repurchase lost due to non-payment.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt dismissed the suit oil May 16, 1950, holding that the transaction on the basis of which the suit was brought was number a mortgage but was out and out sale with an agreement for repurchase and as the vendor had number paid the money punctually according to the terms of the companytract, the right to repurchase was lost and companyld number be specifically enforced , and the companyrt had numberpower to afford any relief against forfeiture of this breach.

facts.text: Plaintiff-respondent appealed to Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 127 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff-respondent took an appeal to the High Court and it was there held that the failure on the part of the respondents to actually tender the amount of the companysideration does riot bar a suit for specific performance

facts.text: High Court held that failure to tender amount does not bar specific performance after repudiation by appellant, allowed appeal and decreed specific performance on May 26, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff-respondent took an appeal to the High Court and it was there held that the failure on the part of the respondents to actually tender the amount of the companysideration does riot bar a suit for specific performance because after the repudiation of the companytract by the appellant, the tender would have been a useless formality. The appeal was therefore allowed and the suit for specific performance decreed.

facts.text: Appellant repudiated the contract by denying concluded or valid agreement for sale.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrespondence which has been proved in this case shows that when the respondents solicitor called upon the appellant to reconvey the property in dispute to the respondent and also sent a draft companyveyance, the appellant denied that there was any companycluded or valid agreement for sale in respect of the property in dispute.

The appeal was therefore allowed and the suit for specific performance decreed.

holdings.text: This was a complete repudiation of the contract to reconvey which the appellant had agreed to by cl. 3 of the agreement which has been set out above.

anchor.surface_text: The correspondence which has been proved in this case shows that when the respondents solicitor called upon the appellant to reconvey the property in dispute to the respondent and also sent a draft conveyance, the appellant denied that there was any concluded or valid agreement for sale in respect of the property in dispute. This was a complete repudiation of the contract to reconvey which the appellant had agreed to by cl. 3 of the agreement which has been set out above.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant's denial of concluded or valid agreement despite cl. 3 constitutes complete repudiation allowing suit for enforcement.

holdings.text: As the appellant had repudiated the contract and had thus failed to carry out his part of the contract it was open to the respondent to sue for its enforcement.

anchor.surface_text: As the appellant had repudiated the contract and had thus failed to carry out his part of the contract it was open to the respondent to sue for its enforcement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Repudiation entitles innocent party to seek specific performance without further performance on their part.

holdings.text: In cases of this kind no question of formal tender of the amount to be paid arises and the question to be decided is not whether any money was within the power of the respondent but whether the appellant definitely and unequivocally, refused to carry out his part of the contract and intimated that money will be refused if tendered.

anchor.surface_text: In cases of this kind no question of formal tender of the amount to be paid arises and the question to be decided is not whether any money was within the power of the respondent but whether the appellant definitely and unequivocally, refused to carry out his part of the contract and intimated that money will be refused if tendered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No formal tender required where repudiation renders it futile, focusing on refusing party's unequivocal refusal.

holdings.text: This principle applies to the facts of the present case also and the question is whether the answer sent on behalf of the appellant amounted to an unequivocal refusal to carry out its part of the contract which in our opinion it was.

anchor.surface_text: This principle applies to the facts of the present case also and the question is whether the answer sent on behalf of the appellant amounted to an unequivocal refusal to carry out its part of the contract which in our opinion it was.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant's reply denying valid agreement qualifies as unequivocal refusal under the futility principle from precedents.

holdings.text: The case upon which the Counsel for the appellant relied, i.e., Ismail Bhai Rahim v. Adam Osman, in our opinion has no application to the facts and circumstances of this case.

anchor.surface_text: The case upon which the Counsel for the appellant relied, i.e., Ismail Bhai Rahim v. Adam Osman, in our opinion has no application to the facts and circumstances of this case. It was held in that case that the offer made by a promisor through a solicitor to pay a debt with interest thereon at the date of the offer does not of itself afford a reasonable opportunity to the promisee of ascertaining that the promisor is able and willing to perform his promise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishing precedent as inapplicable to facts; no peculiar circumstances requiring different rule.

holdings.text: It is difficult to see why a tender made through a solicitor who is for that purpose an agent, is not a proper tender.

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to see why a tender made through a solicitor who is for that purpose an agent, is not a proper tender.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Solicitor acts as agent authorized to make tender on client's behalf.

anchor.surface_text: Hunter v. Daniel  1  is applicable to cases of this kind. In that case Wigram, C., stated the position as follows- The practice of the Courts is number to require a party to make a formal tender where from the facts stated in the Bill or from the evidence it appears the tender would have been a mere form and that the party to whom it was made would have refused to accept the money. Lord Buckmaster in Chalikani Venkatarayanim v. Zamindar of Tuni  2  accepted this statement of the law and observed- Their Lordships think that that is a true and accurate expression of the law, and the question therefore is whether the answer that was sent on behalf of the mortgagee amounted to a clear refusal to accept the money.

precedents.cited_proposition: No formal tender is required if it would be a useless formality because the other party would refuse it
precedents.cited_holding: The practice of the Courts is number to require a party to make a formal tender where from the facts stated in the Bill or from the evidence it appears the tender would have been a mere form and that the party to whom it was made would have refused to accept the money.

precedents.citation: Chalikani Venkatarayanim v. Zamindar of Tuni  2

anchor.surface_text: Chalikani Venkatarayanim v. Zamindar of Tuni  2  accepted this statement of the law and observed- Their Lordships think that that is a true and accurate expression of the law, and the question therefore is whether the answer that was sent on behalf of the mortgagee amounted to a clear refusal to accept the money. This principle applies to the facts of the present case also and the question is whether the answer sent on behalf of the appellant amounted to an unequivocal refusal to carry out its part of the companytract which in our opinion it was. It was next companytended that the offer made by a solicitor is number a proper offer in law and therefore when  1   1845  4 Hare 420 67 E.R. 712.  2   1922  50 I.A. 41, 47. the solicitor for the respondent called upon the appellant to execute the documents they were number bound to do so.

precedents.case_name: Chalikani Venkatarayanim v Zamindar of Tuni
precedents.cited_proposition: The statement in Hunter v Daniel is a true and accurate expression of the law on tender after repudiation
precedents.cited_holding: Their Lordships think that that is a true and accurate expression of the law, and the question therefore is whether the answer that was sent on behalf of the mortgagee amounted to a clear refusal to accept the money.

precedents.citation: Ismail Bhai Rahim v. Adam Osman  1

anchor.surface_text: Ismail Bhai Rahim v. Adam Osman  1 , in our opinion has numberapplication to the facts and circumstances of this case. It was held in that case that the offer made by a promiser through a solicitor to pay a debt with interest thereon at the date of the offer does number of itself afford a reasonable opportunity to the promisee of ascertaining that the promisor is able and willing to perform his promise. Unless there is something peculiar in the circumstances of that case that case does number lay down good law. It is difficult to see why a tender made through a solicitor who is for that purpose an agent, is number a proper tender.

precedents.case_name: Ismail Bhai Rahim v Adam Osman
precedents.cited_proposition: Offer made by a promisor through a solicitor does not afford reasonable opportunity to ascertain ability and willingness to perform
precedents.cited_holding: the offer made by a promiser through a solicitor to pay a debt with interest thereon at the date of the offer does number of itself afford a reasonable opportunity to the promisee of ascertaining that the promisor is able and willing to perform his promise.

anchor.surface_text: The correspondence which has been proved in this case shows that when the respondents solicitor called upon the appellant to reconvey the property in dispute to the respondent and also sent a draft conveyance, the appellant denied that there was any concluded or valid agreement for sale in respect of the property in dispute. This was a complete repudiation of the contract to reconvey which the appellant had agreed to by cl. 3 of the agreement which has been set out above.

The correspondence which has been proved in this case shows that when the respondents solicitor called upon the appellant to reconvey the property in dispute to the respondent and also sent a draft conveyance, the appellant denied that there was any concluded or valid agreement for sale in respect of the property in dispute. This was a complete repudiation of the contract to reconvey which the appellant had agreed to by cl. 3 of the agreement which has been set out above.

anchor.surface_text: In cases of this kind no question of formal tender of the amount to be paid arises and the question to be decided is not whether any money was within the power of the respondent but whether the appellant definitely and unequivocally, refused to carry out his part of the contract and intimated that money will be refused if tendered.

anchor.surface_text: The case upon which the Counsel for the appellant relied, i.e., Ismail Bhai Rahim v. Adam Osman, in our opinion has no application to the facts and circumstances of this case. It was held in that case that the offer made by a promisor through a solicitor to pay a debt with interest thereon at the date of the offer does not of itself afford a reasonable opportunity to the promisee of ascertaining that the promisor is able and willing to perform his promise.
